sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
This record can be found on [PAGE(S)] of REED: Inns of Court, Vol. [#]
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

head.supplied:
THE Inner Temple masque. presented by the gentlemen there Ianuary 13. 1614. (Masque of Ulysses and Circe)
Written by W Browne.
Ovidii ad Pisonem.

div.ab:
nonindented to mid-folio and preceded by a line semper Gnosius arcus
Destinat, exempto sed laxat cornua neruo.‘the Cretan does not always aim the bow, but freeing its string he relaxes the horns’; Anonymous, Laus Pisonis 142–3
To the honorable society of the Inner temple.

Gentlemen.
I giue you but your owne: if you refuse to foster it I knowe not who will. by your meanes it may liue, If it degenerate in kinde from those other our society hath produc’d, blame your selues for not seekinge to a happier muse. I knowe it is not without faultes, yet such as your loues or at least Poetica Licentia (the common salue) will make tollerable. what is good in it yat is yours, what bad myne, what indifferent both, & yat will suffice, since it was done to please our selues in priuate, by him that is
All yours
W Browne.

div.head:
The inner temple maske
The description of the firste scæne
div.stage: On one side the hall towardes the lower end was discouered a cliffe of the sea done ouer in parte white accordinge to that of Vergill libro 5:

epigraph.ab: Iamque adeo scopulos sirenum aduecta subibat Difficiles quondam multorumque ossibus albos‘and conveyed thus far, it (the ship) was approaching the cliffs of the sirens, dangerous of ancient times and white with the bones of many men’; Vergil, Aeneid 5.864–5.

div.stage: Vpon yat were seated two Syrens as they are described by Hyginus & Seruius with their vpper parts like woemen to the nauell and the rest like a hen: One of theese at the firste discouery of the scene (a sea being done in perspectiue on[e] one side the cliffe) began to singe this songe beinge as lasciuious proper to them & begininge as that of theirs in Homer libro μ οδνόείαϛ δενῥάγ ίών πάλναινfor πολναιν Όδνόεῦ χῦδοϛΆχαιων‘come then while you are going, greatly praised Odysseus, the great glory of the Achaeans’; Homer, Odyssey 12.184

lg.l: Steere hither, steere, your winged Pines
All beaten Mariners
Here lye loves vndiscovered Mynes
A prey to passengers.
Perfumes farre sweeter then the best
Which make ye Phœnix vrne and nest
ffeare not your ships
Nor any to oppose you saue our lips
But come on shore
Where no ioy dyes till love hath gotten more

div.stage: The last two lines were repeated as from a groue near by a full Chorus & ye Syren[e] about to singe againe, Triton (in all parts as Apollonius libro 4. Argonauticæ shewes him) was seene interruptinge her thus:

lg.l: Leaue, leaue alluring Syren with thy song
To hasten what ye Fates would faine prolong
Your sweetest tunes but grones of Mandrakes be
He his owne Traytor is yat heareth thee |
Tethys Commaunds nor is it fit yat you
Should ever glory you did him subdue–
By wyles whose pollicyes were never spread
Till Flaming Troy gave light to haue yem read
Vlysses now furrowes ye liquid plaine
Doubtfull of seeing Ithaca againe–
ffor in his way more stops are thrust [be] L by J time
Then in ye path where vertue comes to climbe.
She yat with silver springs for ever fills
The shady groues, sweet meddowes and ye hills
ffrom whose continuall store such pooles are fed
As in ye land for seas are famosed
Tis shee whose fauor to this Grecian tends
And to remove his ruine Triton sends
But ’tis not Tethys, nor a greater powre
Cynthia, that rules the waues, scearce he (each howre)
that weildes the thunderboltes, can thinges begun
By mighty Circe, (daughter to the sun)
Checke or controule; she yat by charmes can make
The scaldedforscaled fish to leaue the brinye lake.
And on the seas walke as on land she were
She that can pull ye pale moone from her spheare,
And at midday the worlds all glorious eye
Muffle with cloudes in longe obscuritie.
She that can cold December set on fire
And from the graue bodyes with life inspire.
She that can Cleaue the center & with ease
A prospect make to our Antipodes
Whose mystique spelles haue fearfull thunders made
And forc’t braue riuers to run retrograde. |
She without stormes that sturdy oakes can tare
And turne their rootes where late their curld toppes wer e
She that can with the winter Solstice bringe
All fflora’s daintyes: Circe bids me singe
And till some [gret] greater hand her power can staye
Who ’ere commaunde, I none but her obaye.

sp.speaker: Triton.
sp.p: Then Nereus daughter thus you’le haue me telle

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I shall. Triton. farewelle.speech heading and Triton’s speech not on new lines in MS

lg.l: Vaine was thy message, vaine her heste, for I
Muste tune againe my wanton Melodye.
Here she went on with her songe thus.
ffor swellinge waues, our pantinge brestes
where neuer stormes arise
Exchange; and be a while our guestes
for starres, gaze on our eyes.
The compasse, loue shall hourely singe,
And as he goes aboute the ringe,
we will not misse
To telle each pointe he nameth with a kisse.

sp.speaker: Chorus

lg.l: Then come on shore.
Where no ioye dyes till loue hath gotten more.

sp.stage: At ye end of this songe Circe was seene vpon the rocke, quaintly attyr’d, her haire loose aboute her shoulders, an Anadem of flowers on her head with a wand in her hand, & then makinge towardes the Syrens cald them thence with this speeche– |

lg.l: Sirens ynouhforynough; cease; Circe hath prævayld,
The Greekes which on ye dauncinge billowes sayld,
Aboute whose shippes a hundred Dolphins clunge
Wrapt with the musicke of Vlisses tongue,
Haue with their guide by powrfull Circe’s hand
Cast their hook’d anchors on Ææa’s strand.
Yonde standes a hille crown’d with high wauinge trees
Whose gallant toppes each neighb’ringe countrye sees.
Vnder whose shade an hundred Syluans playe.
With Gaudy Nymphes farre fairer then ye daye
Where euerlastinge Springe with Syluer showres
Sweete roses doth encrease to grace our bowres.
Where lauish fflora prodigall in pride
Spendes what might well enrich all earth beside,
And to adorne this place shee loues so deare
Stayes in some Clymats scearcely halfe ye yeare.
When would shee to the world indifferent bee,
They should continuall Aprill haue as wee.
Midway ye wood and from ye leueld lands
A spatious yet a curious arbor standes.
Wherein should Phœbus once to pry beginne
I would benight him ’ere he gette his Inne,
Or turne his steedes awrye, so drawe him on
To burne all landes but this like Phaeton.
Vlisses, neere, his mates by my stronge charmes
Lye there till my returne in sleepes soft armes.
Then Syrens quickly wend we to the bowre
To fitte their well-come & shew Circe’s powre.
What all the Elementes doe owe to thee
In their obedience is perform’d in mee.
Circe drinkes not of Lethe, then awaye
To helpe ye Nymphes who now begin their laye. |start of f 11

div.head: The Seconde Scene.
div.stage: While Circe was speakinge her first speech & at theese words Yond standes a hill etc, a trauers was drawne at ye lower end of the hall, & gaue way for the discouery of an artificiall wood so nere imitatinge nature yat I thinke had there beene a groue like yat in ye open plaine, birdes would haue beene faster drawne to that then to Zeuxisxcorrected from another letter grapes. ye trees stood at the climbinge of an hill & lefte at their feete a little plaine, which they circled like a crescente, in this space vpon hillockes were seene, eight musitians in crimson taffity robes with chaplets of lawrell on their heades their lutes by them, which beinge by them toucht as a warninge to ye Nymphes of ye wood, from amonge the trees was hearde this songeline filled out with 13 equally spaced dots

lg.l: What singe the sweete byrdes in each groue?
Nought but loue.
What sound our Eccho, day and night?
All delighte.
What doth each wynd breath vs that fleetes?
Endlesse sweetes.
Is there a place on earth this Isle excelles
Or any Nymphes more happy liue then wee.
When all our songes, our soundes & breathinges bee,
That here all [loue] Loue, Delighte and Sweetenes dwells.

div.stage: By this time Circe & ye Syrens beinge come into ye wood, Vlisses was seene lyeing as asleepe vnder ye couerte of a fair tree, towards whom Circe coming bespake thus:

lg.l: Yet holdes soft sleepe his course. Now Ithacus
Aiax would offer Hecatombes to vs
And Iliums rauish’d wifes & childlesse sires
With incense dym ye bright æthereall fires. |
To haue thee bounde in chaynes of sleepe as heere
But yatforyat thou mayst behold & knowe how deare
Thou art to Circe, with my magicke deepe
And powerfull verses, thus I banish sleepe.
Sonne of Erebus & nighte
Hye away; and aime thy flighte,
Where consorte none other fowle
Then ye batte & sullen owle
Where vpon the lymber grasse
Poppy & Mandragoras
With like simples not a fewe
Hange for euer droppes of dewe.
Where flowes Lethe, with out coyle
Softly like a streame of oyle.
Hye thee thither gentle Sleepe
With this Greeke no longer keepe.
Thrice I charge thee by my wand,
Thrice with [Moly] Moly from my hand
Doe I to touch Vlisses eyes
And with the Iaspis: Then arise–
Sagest Greekespeech concludes with 11 equally spaced dots

div.stage: Vlisses (as by ye powre of Circe) awakinge thus began.

lg.l: Thouspeech preceded by 9 equally spaced dots more then mortalle mayde
Who when thou listes canst make (as if afraide)
The mountaines tremble & with terrour shake
The seate of Dis; & from Auernus lake
Grim Hecate with all the furyes bringe
To work reuenge; or to thy quæstioninge |
Disclose the secrettes of th’infernall shades
Or raise the ghostes yat walke the vnder-glades.
To thee, whom all obey, Vlisses bendes,
But may I aske (Greate Circe) whereto tendes
Thy neuer failinge handes? Shall we be free?
Or must thyne anger crush my mates & mee?
Neyther, Laertes sonne. With winges of loue
To thee & none but thee, my actions moue.
My arte went with thee & thou me mayst thanke
In winninge Rhesus horses, ’ere they dranke
Of Xanthus streame; & when with humane gore
Cleare Hebrus channell was all stayned ’ore;
When some braue Greekes companions then with thee
Forgot their country through the Lotos tree.
I tyn’d the firebrande that (beside thy flight)
Left Polyphemus in eternall nighte.
And lastly to Ææa brought thee on
Safe from the man-deuouring Læstrigon.
This for Vlisses loue hath Circe done.
And if to liue with mee thou shalt be wonne;
Aurora’s hand shall neuer drawe awaye
The sable vale yat hides ye gladsome daye.
But we new pleasures will beginne to taste
And better, stille, those we enioyed laste.
To instance what I canne: Musicke, thy voyce
And of all those haue felte our wrath the choyce
Appeare; and in a dance ’gin that delight
Which with the minutes shall growe infinite.

div.stage: Here one attir’d like a woodman in all poyntes came forth of ye wood & goeinge towr’ds ye stage sunge this songe, to call away ye firste Antimasqueline filled out with 10 equally spaced dots |

lg.l: Come yee whose hornsscorrected from other letters the cuckold weares,
The whittoll too with asses eares,
Let the wolfe leaue howlinge,
The Baboone his scowlinge,
And Grillus hye
Out of his stye.
Though gruntinge, though barkinge, though brayeinge, yee come,
Wee’le make yee daunce quiet and so send yee home.
No ginne shall snare you
Nor Mastiue scare you,
Nor learne the baboones trickes
Nor Grillus scoffe,
ffrom the hogge troughe.
But turne Againe vnto the thickes.
Here’s none (’tis hop’d) so foolish, scornes
That any els should weare the hornes
Here’s no Curre with howlinge
Nor an ape with scowlinge
Shall mocke or moe
At what you showe.
In iumpinge, in skippinge, in turninge or oughte
You shall doe to please vs, how well or how noughte.
If there be any
Amonge this many
Whom such an humour steares
May he still lye[r]
In Grillus stye
Or weare for euer the Asses eares.

div.p: While ye firste staffe of this songe was singinge out of ye thickets on eyther side ye Boscage came rushinge ye Antimasque, beinge such as by Circe were supposed to haue beene transformed (hauinge ye mindes of men still) into these shapes followinge. |start of f 13

lg.note: The musicke was composed of treble violins with all the ...eed party, A base violle, base lute, sagbut, cornamute, & taber & pipe.
lg.l: 2. with heartes, heades & bodyes as Actæon is pictur’d.
2. like Midas with Asses eares.
2. like wolues as Lycaon is drawne.
2. like Baboones.
Grillus (of whom Plutarch writes in his morralles) in ye shape of a hogge.

div.stage: Theese togither dancinge an Antike measure tow’rdes ye latter end of yt missed Grillus who was newly slipte away, & whilst they were at a stand, wondringe what was become of him, the woodman stepte forth & sunge this songe.

lg.l: Grillus is gone, belike he hath hearde:
The dayry-maid knocke at ye trough in ye yearde.
Through thicke & thinne he wallowes
And weighes nor depthes nor shallowes.
Harke how he whynes
Run all ’ere he dines.
Then serue him a tricke
ffor beinge so quicke
And lette him for all his paines
Behold you turne cleane of
His troughe
And spill all his wash & his graines.

div.p: With this ye Triplex of yeir tune was plaid twice or thrice ouer & by turnes brought them from ye stage; when ye woodman sung this other staffe of ye laste songe, & then ran after them:

lg.l: And Now ’tis wish’d yat all such as hee
Were rootinge with him at ye trough or ye tree.
ffly, fly, from our pure fountaines
To the darke vales or the mountaines.
Liste some one whynes
With voyce like a swines,
As Angry yat none
With Grillus is gone. |
Or yat he is lefte behinde.
O let there be no staye
In his waye
To hinder the Boare from his kinde.
Muchspeech preceded by 12 equally spaced dots like to one
Who in a shipwracke beinge cast vpon
The froathy shores and safe beholdes his mates
Equally cross’d by Neptune and the fates
You might as well haue ask’d how I would like
A straine whose æquall Orpheus could not strike,
Vpon a harpe whose stringes none other bee
Then of the harte of chaste Penelope.
O let it be enough that thou in theese
Hast made most wretched Laertiades.
Let not the sad chance of distressed Greekes
With other teares then sorrowes dewe your cheekes
Most abiecte basenesse hath enthral’d that breste
Which laughes at men by misery oppreste.
In this, as Lyllies or ye new falne snowe
Is Circe spotlesse yet. What though the bowe
Which Iris bendes, appeareth to each sight
In various hewes & colours infinite?
The learned knowe that in it selfe is free
And light And shade make that varietye.
Thinges farre of seene seeme not the same they are,
ffame is not euer truth’s Discouerer;
for still where enuy meeteth a reporte
Ill she makes worse, & what is Good come shorte. |
In whatso’ere this land hath passiue beene
Or she that here ’ore other raigneth queene
Let wise Vlisses judg. Some I confesse
That towr ’ds this Ile not longe since did addresse
Their stretched oares, no sooner landed were,
but (carelesse of themselues) they heere & there
fed on strange fruites, inuenominge their bloodes
And Now like monsters range about the woods.
If those thy mates were yet is Circe free
for their misfortunes haue not byrth from mee.
Who in th’ Apothecaries shoppe hath ta’ne
(Whilst he is wantinge) that which breeds his bane
should neuer blame the man who there had plac’d it
But his owne folly vrginge him to taste it.
Ææa’s queene, and Great Hyperions pride
Pardon misdoubtes; and we are satisfi’de.
Swifter the lightninge comes not from aboue
Then doe our grants borne on the wings of Loue.
And since what’s past doth not Vlisses please
Call to a dance the faire Nereides
With other Nymphes which doe in euery creeke
In woods, on plaines, on mountaines symples seeke
for powerfull Circe, and let in a songe
Eccho’s be aydinge that they may prolonge
My now command to each place where they bee
To bringe them hither all more Speedilye.

div.stage: Presently in ye wood was heard a full musicke of Lutes which descendinge to the stage had to them sung this followinge songe, the Eccho’s being plac’d in seuerall parts of the Boscage |line filled out with 3 equally spaced dots

lg.l: Circe bids you come awaye
Eccho: come away, come awaye.
ffrom ye riuers, from the sea,
Eccho: from the sea, from the sea.
from ye Greene woods euery one,
Eccho: euery one, euery one,
Of her maides be missinge none,
Eccho: missinge none, missinge none.
No longer stay except it bee to bringe.
A med’cine for loues stinge.
That would excuse you & be held more deare
Then witte or Magicke for both they are here.
Eccho: They are here, they are here.

p.stage: The Eccho had no sooner aunswerd to ye last line of the songe, They are here, but the second Antimasque came in: beinge seauen Nymphes & were thus attir’d:

div.p: In white taffita robes longe tresses & chaplets of flowers. herbes & weeds on their heades with little wicketforwicker baskets in yeir hands, neatly painted. theese were supposed to be maids attendinge vpon Circe, & vsd in gatheringe simples for theire mistresses inchantments — Pausanias in prioribus Eliacis'Pausanias in his first book on Elis'./

In sea greene robes* greenish haire hanginge loose, with leaues of corrall & shelles intermixte vpon it; Theese are by Ouid affirmed to helpe the ThreeNymphes of Circe in their collections: by theese:

lg.l: Nereides Nymphæque simul quis vellera motis
Nulla trahunt digitosfor digitis, nec fila sequentia ducunt
Gramina disponunt; sparsosque sine ordine flores
Secernunt Calathis, varijsque coloribus herbas.
Ipsa quod hæ faciunt opus exigit, &c.Ovid, Metamorphoses 14.264-8/ |start of f 15

div.p: Theese hauinge danc’d a most curious measure to a softer tune then ye first Antimasque as most fitting returnd as they came, the Nereides tow’rds ye cliffes & ye other maides of Circe to ye woods & plaines, after which Vlisses, thus.

lg.l: ffame addes not to thy ioyes I see in this;
But like a high & stately Pyramis
Growes least at farthest; Now faire Circe grante
Although the faire hair’d Greekes do neuer vaunte:
That they in measur’d paces ought haue done,
But where the god of Battailes ledd them on;
Giue leaue that (freed from sleepe) the small remaine
Of my companions; on the vnder plaine
May in a dance striue how to pleasure thee
Eyther with skill or with varietye.
Circe is pleas’d, Vlisses take my wand
And from their eyes each child of sleepe command.
Whilst my choyce maides with their harmonious voyces
(Whereat each byrd and dancinge springe reioyces)
Ha[minge]L rmingeJ the windes when they contrary meete
shall make their spirits as nimble as their feete.

div.p: Circe with this speech deliueringe her wande to Vlisses rests on ye lower parte of ye hill, while he goeing vp the hill & strikinge ye trees with his wand, suddainly two greate gates flew open, makinge as it were a large glade through the wood, & a longe ye glade a faire walke, twoe seeminge bricke walles on eyther side, ouer which the trees wantonly hunge, a great light (at ye suns suddaine | vnmaskinge) being seene vpon this discouery. At ye further end was descride an arbour, very curiously done, hauinge one entrance vnder an Architraue borne vp by two pillers with their chapters & bases [Guilte] Guilte, ye top of ye entrance beautifi’de with pituresfor pictures of Satyres Wood Nymphes, & other Anticke worke, as also ye sides & corners; The coueringe Archwise interwoue with boughes, ye backe of it girte round with [a] vine & artificially done vp in knottes towards ye toppe; beyond it was a wood seene in perspectiue, The fore parte of it opening at Vlisses his approach, the maskers were discouered in seuerall seates leaninge as a sleape.

Doublets of greene taffita cut like oaken leaues, as vpon cloth of syluer, their skirtes & winges cut into leaues, deepe round hose of ye same, both laid with sprigge lace spangled, longe white sylke stockins, greene pumpes & roses done ouer with syluer leaues, hattes of ye same stuffe & cut narrowe brim’d, & risinge smaller compasse at ye crowne, white wreath hatbandes, white plumes egrettes with a greene fall, Ruffs, bands & cuffes.

p.stage: Vlisses seuerally came & touch’t euery one of them with ye wand while this was sunge.

lg.l: Shake of sleepe yee worthy knights
Though yee dreame of all delights
Shew that Venus doth resorte
To the campe as well as courte.
By some well-timed measure
And on your gestures & your paces
Let the well-composed Graces
Lokinge like and parte with pleasure.

p.stage: By this ye knights beinge all risen from their seates were by Vlisses (ye loud musicke soundinge) brought to ye stage; & then to the violins danced their first measure, after which this songe brought them to the second. |

lg.l: On & imitate ye [moone] ^ L SunJ
Stay not to breath till you haue done
Earth doth thinke as otherwhere
Do some woemen she doth beare
Those wifes whose husbands onely threaten
Are not lou’d like those are beaten.
Then with your feete to suffringe moue her
ffor whilst you beate earth thus you loue her.

p.stage: Here they danc’t there second measure & then this songe was sunge duringe which time they take out ye l[e]L a J dyes:

lg.l: Choose now amonge this fairest number
Vpon whose brestes loue would for euer slumber:
Choose not amisse since you may where you wylle
Or blame your selues for choosing Ille.
Then doe not leaue though ofte the musicke closes
Till lillyes in their cheekes be turn’d to roses.
And if it lay in Circe’s power
Your blisse might so perseuer
That Those you choose but for a hower
You should enioy for euer.

p.stage: The knights with the ladyes dance here ye old measures, Galliards, Corantoes, The Braules, &c. And then (hauinge lead them againe to their places) daunced their laste measure. after which this songe called them awaye. |

lg.l: who but Tyme so hasty were
To fly away & leaue you here.
Here where delight
Might well allure
A very stoicke from this night
To turne an Epicure.
But since he calles away; And Time will soone repente,
He staid not longer here, but ran, to be more Idly spente.
